skos.definition: Serum sodium concentration below 135 mEq/L, the most common electrolyte abnormality in hospitalized patients, caused by relative excess of water to sodium and classified by serum osmolality and volume status.
skos.scopeNote: Most common electrolyte disorder; associated with increased morbidity and mortality if not managed properly

content.title: Hyponatremia
content.summary: Hyponatremia is serum sodium <135 mEq/L, the most common electrolyte disorder. The approach involves determining serum osmolality (true hypotonic vs pseudohyponatremia), then assessing volume status to identify the underlying cause. Treatment varies dramatically based on acuity, symptoms, and etiology, with careful attention to correction rate to prevent osmotic demyelination syndrome.
key_points: First step: Check serum osmolality to exclude pseudohyponatremia (hyperlipidemia, hyperproteinemia) and translocational (hyperglycemia)
Hypotonic hyponatremia: Classify by volume status (hypovolemic, euvolemic, hypervolemic)
SIADH is most common cause of euvolemic hypotonic hyponatremia
Symptoms correlate with rate of development more than absolute level
Correction rate: <8-10 mEq/L in 24 hours to prevent osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS)
Severe symptoms (seizures, coma): 3% hypertonic saline 100-150 mL boluses
Check urine Na and osmolality to differentiate causes
content.statement: Hyponatremia reflects an imbalance between water and sodium homeostasis, with the kidney's handling of water (mediated by ADH) being central to most causes. A systematic approach evaluating tonicity and volume status allows accurate diagnosis and guides appropriate therapy while avoiding the serious complication of osmotic demyelination.

explanation.intuition: Think of sodium as 'dissolved' in body water - a low sodium level usually means too much water relative to sodium (dilutional), not too little sodium. The key question is: Why can't the kidney excrete the excess water? Usually, ADH is present when it shouldn't be (SIADH) or the kidney is responding appropriately to a perceived volume deficit.
explanation.key_insight: Urine osmolality is the most useful test: If <100 mOsm/kg, the kidney is appropriately diluting urine (primary polydipsia or reset osmostat). If >100 mOsm/kg, ADH is present (appropriate or inappropriate). Then urine sodium helps distinguish volume depletion (<20 mEq/L) from SIADH (>40 mEq/L).
explanation.technical_details: ADH (vasopressin) is released in response to hyperosmolality or hypovolemia. It binds V2 receptors in collecting duct, inserting aquaporin-2 channels and concentrating urine. In SIADH, ADH is secreted despite normal/low osmolality. Correction too rapidly allows brain cells to shrink (they had adapted by losing organic osmolytes), leading to osmotic demyelination of pontine and extrapontine white matter.

definitions_glossary.hypotonic_hyponatremia: True hyponatremia with serum osmolality <280 mOsm/kg; most common form
definitions_glossary.pseudohyponatremia: Falsely low sodium due to hyperlipidemia or hyperproteinemia with normal osmolality; artifact of measurement
definitions_glossary.translocational_hyponatremia: Water shift from cells due to effective osmoles (glucose, mannitol); high or normal osmolality
definitions_glossary.SIADH: Syndrome of inappropriate ADH - euvolemic hypotonic hyponatremia with inappropriately concentrated urine
definitions_glossary.osmotic_demyelination_syndrome: ODS - brain injury from overly rapid sodium correction; affects pons (central pontine myelinolysis) and/or extrapontine areas
definitions_glossary.urine_sodium: Low (<20 mEq/L) in volume depletion; high (>40 mEq/L) in SIADH, salt-wasting, diuretics
definitions_glossary.urine_osmolality: Concentrated (>100 mOsm/kg) indicates ADH activity; dilute indicates appropriate water excretion
definitions_glossary.cerebral_salt_wasting: Renal sodium loss after CNS injury; hypovolemic unlike SIADH
definitions_glossary.polydipsia: Excessive water intake; can cause hyponatremia if exceeds renal diluting capacity (>15-20 L/day)
definitions_glossary.vasopressin_receptor_antagonist: Vaptans - block V2 receptor to promote aquaresis; used for euvolemic/hypervolemic hyponatremia
definitions_glossary.aquaresis: Electrolyte-free water excretion; promoted by blocking ADH effect
definitions_glossary.serum_osmolality: Measure of dissolved particles; calculated as 2×Na + glucose/18 + BUN/2.8
definitions_glossary.free_water_restriction: First-line treatment for SIADH; limit intake to 500-1000 mL/day
definitions_glossary.hypertonic_saline: 3% NaCl (513 mEq/L); used for severe symptomatic hyponatremia

pathophysiology.mechanism: Hyponatremia almost always reflects impaired water excretion. Normally, kidneys can dilute urine to 50 mOsm/kg, excreting >15 L/day. ADH impairs this dilution. Causes include: appropriate ADH (hypovolemia, decreased effective arterial volume) and inappropriate ADH (SIADH).

by_osmolality.hypotonic: <280 mOsm/kg - true hyponatremia with excess water

by_volume_status.hypovolemic: GI losses, diuretics, adrenal insufficiency, cerebral salt wasting
by_volume_status.euvolemic: SIADH, hypothyroidism, glucocorticoid deficiency, primary polydipsia
by_volume_status.hypervolemic: Heart failure, cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome, renal failure

pathophysiology.brain_adaptation: Chronic hyponatremia: brain cells lose organic osmolytes (glutamate, taurine, myo-inositol) to prevent edema. Rapid correction before reaccumulation causes cell shrinkage and demyelination.

acute_vs_chronic.acute: Develops in <48 hours; higher risk of cerebral edema and herniation
acute_vs_chronic.chronic: Develops over >48 hours; brain-adapted; higher risk of ODS if corrected rapidly

interpretation.urine_osm_less_100: Maximally dilute urine → primary polydipsia or reset osmostat
interpretation.urine_osm_greater_100: ADH is present → check urine sodium

SIADH_criteria: Urine sodium >40 mEq/L (on normal salt intake)

severe_symptoms.treatment: 3% hypertonic saline 100-150 mL IV bolus over 10-20 minutes
severe_symptoms.repeat: Can repeat 2-3 times if symptoms persist
severe_symptoms.goal: Raise Na by 4-6 mEq/L to reverse symptoms
severe_symptoms.monitoring: Check sodium every 1-2 hours during active treatment

correction_limits.standard: Correct <8-10 mEq/L in first 24 hours, <18 mEq/L in 48 hours
correction_limits.high_risk_ODS: Correct <6-8 mEq/L in 24 hours (chronic, malnutrition, alcoholism, hypokalemia)

overcorrection_rescue.indication: Sodium rising faster than target rate
overcorrection_rescue.goal: Re-lower sodium to safe correction rate

by_etiology.hypovolemic: Isotonic saline (NS) - restores volume and suppresses ADH
by_etiology.SIADH: Fluid restriction (500-1000 mL/day), salt tabs, loop diuretics ± vaptans
by_etiology.hypervolemic: Fluid and sodium restriction, treat underlying cause, consider vaptans

vaptans.indication: Euvolemic or hypervolemic hyponatremia not responding to conservative measures
vaptans.monitoring: Initiate in hospital, check sodium frequently

prognosis.ODS_risk_factors: Chronic hyponatremia, alcoholism, malnutrition, hypokalemia, sodium <105
prognosis.outcomes: Good if properly managed; ODS is rare but devastating (locked-in syndrome, death)

learning_objectives: Classify hyponatremia by serum osmolality and volume status
Apply a systematic diagnostic approach using urine osmolality and urine sodium
Recognize SIADH criteria and common causes
Calculate safe sodium correction rates to prevent osmotic demyelination syndrome
Describe emergency management of severe symptomatic hyponatremia
Explain the mechanism of osmotic demyelination syndrome
clinical_pearls: Urine osmolality is the most useful single test - if <100, kidneys are working normally (polydipsia)
Correct glucose before assessing sodium: Add 1.6-2.4 mEq/L Na for every 100 mg/dL glucose above normal
SIADH requires euvolemia + concentrated urine + high urine sodium + exclusion of thyroid/adrenal disease
Overcorrection is dangerous - have a low threshold for D5W and desmopressin
Hypokalemia correction raises serum sodium - account for this when planning
Tea and toast diet causes hyponatremia from low solute intake (beer potomania variant)

high_yield_topics: Interpretation of urine osm and urine Na
common_question_stems: Patient with lung cancer and Na 118, urine osm 400, urine Na 55
Post-operative patient with confusion and Na 121
Alcoholic patient with rapid correction and subsequent quadriplegia
CHF patient with Na 128 and edema
exam_tips: Step 1: Check serum osm. Step 2: Check urine osm. Step 3: Check urine Na.
SIADH = euvolemic + concentrated urine + high urine Na
Overcorrection → ODS → re-lower with D5W and DDAVP

teaching_cases.scenario: 68-year-old with small cell lung cancer, Na 119, serum osm 255, urine osm 520, urine Na 65, clinically euvolemic
teaching_cases.key_findings: Hypotonic, inappropriately concentrated urine with high urine sodium, euvolemic, no thyroid/adrenal disease
teaching_cases.diagnosis: SIADH secondary to small cell lung cancer (paraneoplastic)
teaching_cases.management: Fluid restriction 1 L/day, salt tablets, monitor Na, consider tolvaptan if refractory
